72471.description:
Zombie Manor II is a mini-game that is included with the terrain model set "Wildwood Grove." Besides the change in setting, it expands the original Zombie Manor by adding new monsters and treasures. This set can be combined with the contents of "Zombie Manor I" to create a longer game and add variety.

From the rules introduction:

The objective of the game is to search the Graveyard for the ring of Lady Coreanne Swarthington. The Graveyard is not completely abandoned however, as strange forces (or perhaps even the curse of the ring itself) conspire to make it a focus of foul magics and a home to misshapen creatures that never should have been. Will you recover the lost ring, or will you find your own grave in Wildwood Grove?

Link: http://www.worldworksgames.com/store/index.php?main_page=pro...;products_id=288
72471.name: Zombie Manor II

72472.name: Kid Icarus
72472.description:
"Kid Icarus is a platforming video game in which the player controls Pit in sprite-rendered two-dimensional landscapes. Pit starts the game with a bow and arrows as his only weapon, and with only the ability to jump. The player explores more areas and collects power-ups that grant Pit special abilities and enhance his armor and weaponry. The gameplay incorporates elements of action and adventure games. In addition to common enemies, Pit encounters bosses that he needs to defeat to progress."

Source: Wikipedia, "Kid_Icarus_(video_game)," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

72473.name: Rollergames
72473.description:
[User Summary]

Rollergames is a scrolling beat 'em up on roller blades, loosely based on the Rollergames franchise and television show. In addition to the typical fighting of the beat 'em up genre, it features platforming elements and a unique sense of speed.

72474.name: Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back (Parker Brothers)
72474.description:
From the Game Manual

The Empire's revenge has begun! Right now an army of Imperial Walkers is marching toward the Rebels' power generator on the Ice Planet Hoth. If they reach it, the entire Rebel base will blow sky high! To stop them, the Rebels must rely on their missile-firing Snowspeeders. The Snowspeeders may be tiny (compared to the gigantic Imperial Walkers) but they're quick and agile. And in the hands of a skillful commander, they can destroy the mighty Walkers!

So climb into your Snowspeeder and be prepared to meet the first of your deadly enemies!

72475.name: Street Fighter 2010: The Final Fight
72475.description:
"Street Fighter 2010: The Final Fight, released in Japan as 2010 Street Fighter, is a sci-fi-themed action platform game released by Capcom for the Nintendo Entertainment System in 1990. 2010 was marketed in Japan and North America as a futuristic sequel to the 1987 arcade fighting game Street Fighter, although its story was rewritten for its English localization to further strengthen the connection between the two games."

Source: Wikipedia, "Street_Fighter_2010," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

72476.name: Mayhem Skate!
72476.description:
An urban skating game included in the cardstock model set "Urban Grind" published from Worldworks Games.

From the publisher:
Mayhem: Urban Grind is a skate park, standees and mini-game all in one! Design the park of your dreams and furnish it with all the ramp and grind combos you can handle! Once constructed build up an army of skater dudes to inhabit the park and cause completely mayhem!

As mentioned, this release includes "Mayhem Skate"; a skate park themed multiplayer game which pits your skater against others in an exhibition style or racing format challenge! Includes a number of game variants to spice up the competition! Fun, fast and sweeeeet!
Mayhem: Urban Grind includes all of the following (All skate park terrain comes in both graffiti and "clean" versions)

72478.description:
Game Description
You and your hideous troll-friends have decided that it’s time for a career change. You are tired of guarding bridges and shaking down weary travelers all for the sake of a few clinking coins! Tolls are down, bandits are up, and besides, living under your bridge is damp and uncomfortable-—and breathing all that crumbling bridge mortar is taking a toll on your lungs...

It’s time to venture forth and find some fresh sea air! In Trollhalla, you join forces with your fellow trolls to sail the seas in search of islands filled with pillage and plunder. Crunchy livestock, nervous monks, panicked princesses, piles of gold, and casks of grog await you! But watch out for Billy Goats--if you’re not careful they will knock parts of your precious stolen cargo out of your boat!

With so many goodies lying about on these islands, it feels like you’ve died and gone to troll heaven, or perhaps someplace even better -- Trollhalla!

Object
Players take turns placing trolls on the board. Trolls emerge from below each ship’s deck ready to plunder and scout the seas of Trollhalla! Trolls placed on ships claim plunder from nearby islands when a ship sails. Trolls placed in the sea will scout for destinations and determine where these ships sail, and also award players cards that perform special actions. The player who uses his trolls to fill his private boat with the most valuable collection of plunder wins the game!
72478.name: Trollhalla

72479.name: Legacy of the Wizard
72479.description:
"Legacy of the Wizard is a fantasy-themed, action-adventure platform game released for the MSX and Famicom in Japan and for the Nintendo Entertainment System in the United States. The game chronicles the story of the Drasle family's attempt to destroy an ancient, evil dragon named Keela that is magically entrapped in a painting within an underground labyrinth. The only way the Drasle family can accomplish their goal is to use the "Dragon Slayer", a magical sword that is protected by four hidden crowns. The player must use the unique abilities of each member of the family to regain possession of the crowns, so that they may use the Dragon Slayer to defeat the evil Keela.

Like many games of its era, the story of Legacy of the Wizard is explained almost entirely in the game's instruction manual. The game itself contains very little text, and does little to add to or even to explain the story of the game.

Legacy of the Wizard is the fourth installment in Falcom's Dragon Slayer series."

Source: Wikipedia, "Legacy_of_the_Wizard," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

72480.name: L'esprit de Riquet
72480.description:
First mini-expansion for the game "Arriala, canal de Garonne".
The expansion only contains the figure of Pierre-Paul Riquet and the rules.

In the beginning of the game "Riquet" is placed on the village "Montauban".
"Riquet" can be moved by the active player, so "Riquet" can help with the construction of "Canal de Garonne". He's considered as a worker and follows the basic rules of occupying a place on the canal.

The active player can:
- move "Riquet" one time from one village to another village,
- use some of his actionpoints to move "Riquet" one or more places on the canal.
You can't move "Riquet" to the vinyards or the structures by the canal and you can't use cards to move "Riquet".

When a section of the canal is completed with the help of "Riquet", the active player may choose which colour Riquet is to be considered.

source: free translation of the official rules

72481.name: Kabuki Quantum Fighter
72481.description:
[User Summary]

Kabuki Quantum Fighter is an action platformer featuring a soldier who transmits his brain via binary code into a defense computer to take on an evil artificial intelligence using the power of his ancestors. Or more specifically, the power of their wacky kabuki hair.

72482.description:
Heroes of Graxia is a deck building game for 2-6 players that features dynamic gameplay using cards in a fantasy strategy-based environment.

The game uses cards to represent forces on the gameplay table. Starting with a small deck of 12 cards, players build their empire by buying the best cards to prepare them to out-smart and out-maneuver other players to obtain trophies and prestige in the World of Graxia.

The game will contain more than 240 unique cards at release, as well as miniatures. Buy for your deck the best Weapons, Armor, Spells, Armies, Henchmen, and Mercenary cards. Conquer enemies by playing these cards on the gameplay table in a sequence of turns with other players.

As Players defeat Units and Heroes of opposing Legions, they gain Prestige by taking the appropriate Prestige Point cards and placing them in their Loot Pile. These points are tallied the end of the game to determine the winner. Player’s may examine the Loot Pile of each other at any time.

The fantasy world of Graxia is filled with mysteries designed for players to discover and solve. Why are there huge continents floating in the sky? Why is there such a wide variety of races living on each of these continents when travel between these lands is only accomplished through the use of Guardian created magical portals?

Only selecting your favorite Guardian, exploring the world, and commanding your armies in battle, provides the answers to some of the Graxian mysteries.

Heroes of Graxia is not a CCG. It is a deck building card game based on the Graxia universe and Guardians of Graxia board game published by Petroglyph.
72482.name: Heroes of Graxia
boardgamepodcastepisode: The Little Metal Dog Show - Episode 6

72483.name: Ghosts 'n Goblins
videogameversion: North American Game Boy Color edition
videogamefranchise: Capcom Grid Series (Early Capcom NES Games, US)
videogamehonor: 1986 Golden Joystick Best Arcade-Style Game of the Year Nominee
72483.description:
"Ghosts 'n Goblins is a platform game where the player controls a knight, named Sir Arthur, who must defeat zombies, demons and other undead creatures in order to rescue Princess Prin Prin, who has been kidnapped by Satan, King of Demon World. Along the way the player can pick up new weapons, bonuses and extra suits of armor that can help in this task.

The game is often considered very difficult by arcade standards and is commonly regarded as one of the most difficult games ever released. The game is considered by Gametrailers.com to be the world's second most difficult game ever made. The player can only be hit twice before losing a life. If the player loses a life, he is returned to the start of the level, or the halfway point if he has managed to get that far. Furthermore, each life can only last a certain length of time (generally around three minutes), the clock being reset at the start of a level. If the clock does run out, the player instantly loses that life."

Source: Wikipedia, "Ghosts_'n_Goblins," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Individual credits:
Mark Cooksey: Music (C64)

72484.name: Little Lovers She So Game
72484.description:
User summary:

A "romance tactics digital board game", the player takes turns rolling the virtual dice and moving on the virtual game board, and gets to choose from different options depending on which space he lands on.

There are six girls in the game's "story", and the goal of the game is to get one of them to fall in love with you once the game ends.

72485.name: Monster Party
72485.description:
"Monster Party is a video game for the NES, released in the U.S. in 1989 by Bandai. It was and remains a relatively obscure platform game for the console, having a small following among some players. Prototype screenshots of a Japanese Famicom version exist, but the game was never released in Japan.

Monster Party is very standard platform game featuring horror themes. The main character, Mark, teams up with a gargoyle-looking creature called Bert, and together they attempt to save Bert's home, the Dark World.

Monster Party is notorious for prototype images released in Japan before the game's release in the US. The Japanese images of the game reveal the title screen to be covered in blood and the enemies to look much more horrific than in the final game.

Critics of the game almost always cite the game as being bizarre and note that the weird factors of the game are what make it stand out. The 8-bit blood and the use of the word "hell" in a later level also interests critics, as Bandai and Nintendo were big supporters of video game censorship in 1989 when the game was released."

Source: Wikipedia, "Monster_Party," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

72486.name: Parodius
videogameversion: Japanese Playstation release (Konami Antiques MSX collection)
Japanese Saturn release (Konami Antiques MSX collection Ultra Pack)
72486.description:
User summary from Japanese Wikipedia:

A typical "cute'em-up", a horizontal shoot'em-up with a cute fantasy theme and a parody of Gradius. Parodius was originally released for the MSX and is the first in the Parodius series. The goal of the game is to defeat the bugs that eat people's dreams.

The game system is the same as in Gradius, but with the added Bell system from Twinbee. There are five selectable characters, but they all use the same weapon system. The title screen and the stars on each stage are parodies of Gradius 2 for the MSX.

Trivia: It is said that Parodius was a game developed as a stress relief for the staff as the production of "Snatcher" took its time, and that that would be the reason why Parodius contains such weird effects and vulgar graphics. There are many places where the players have to resort to strange methods to even advance through the stages.

Source: Wikipedia, "パロディウス," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

72487.name: Life Force
videogameversion: English/European Commodore 64/128 (The Hit Squad re-release) Cassette editon
English/European ZX Spectrum 48 / 128 / +2 / +3 (The Hit Squad re-release) Cassette editon
72487.description:
"Salamander (沙羅曼蛇), retitled Life Force in North America and in the Japanese arcade re-release, is a scrolling shooter arcade game by Konami. Released in 1986 as a spin-off to Gradius, Salamander introduced a simplified power-up system, two-player cooperative gameplay and both horizontally and vertically scrolling stages. Some of these would later become the norm for future Gradius games."

Source: Wikipedia, "Salamander_(video_game)," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

72488.name: It's Parodius!: From Myth to Laughter
videogameversion: Japanese Playstation release (Deluxe Parodius da! package)
Japanese Saturn release (Deluxe Parodius da! package)
72488.description:
User summary (details from Japanese Wikipedia):

An arcade shooting game from 1990, developped by Konami. It's the sequel to "Parodius" for the MSX in 1988.

Parodius da! is a typical "cute'em-up", a shoot'em-up with a cute bubbly fantasy theme. It's based as a parody of Gradius and follows the same game system, borrowing some essences from the cute'em-up Twinbee.

The arcade was so popular that the game was ported to an astonishing number of platforms, from the Famicon in 1990 to the PSP in 2007.

Source: Wikipedia, "パロディウスだ!_〜神話からお笑いへ〜," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

72489.name: Deluxe Parodius – Pursue the Glory of the Past
videogameversion: Japanese Playstation release (Deluxe Parodius da! bundle package)
Japanese PSP release (Parodius Portable bundle package)
Japanese Saturn release (Deluxe Parodius da! bundle package)
72489.description:
User summary, (details translated from Japanese Wikipedia):

The third installment in the Parodius series by Konami, Deluxe Parodius (Gokujou Parodius) was first released for the arcades in 1994 and then ported to several home systems.

In its base a parody of Konami's "Gradius", Parodius is a "cute'em-up", a shoot'em-up with a cute fantasy theme, running on the same base system as Gradius and borrowing from the cute'em-up Twinbee.

The bundle "Deluxe Parodius da!" for the Playstation and Sega Saturn was released in Europe under the title "Fantastic Journey".

Source: Wikipedia, "極上パロディウス_〜過去の栄光を求めて〜," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

72490.name: The Rifter (Issue 16 - Oct 2001)
rpgissuearticle: From the desk of Kevin Siembieda
HLS adventures for Rift Coalition Wars: THe Final Siege
72490.description:
From the back of the book

• Questions and Answers.
• Palladium Fantasy RPG source material covering Orcs, Goblins and their kin.
• Tons of Nightbane source material, detailing a secret war between good and evil, and the soldiers who fight it.
• Heroes Unlimited™ rules for making Teen Heroes.
• Historical adventure for use with Ninjas & Superspies™ or RECON.
• Rifts adventures for the Siege on Tolkeen™.
• Rifts: A continuing short story (part two of three).
• Rifts: Hammer of the Forge™ (fiction).
• A sneak preview of the upcoming After the Bomb RPG!
• 112 pages of fun!
• Cat. No. 116

72491.name: The Rifter (Issue 21 - Jan 2003)
rpgissuearticle: From the Desk of Kevin Siembieda
A glimpse at the Palladium Fantasy Series.
72491.description:
From the back of the book

The Rifter Number Twenty-One

The Rifter is a vehicle to numerous Palladium role-playing worlds. It is a tool for Game Masters and player alike. A place to showcase new talent and exchange ideas for the entire Palladium Megaverse. Every issue, unique and informative.
Issue number 21 is packed with news and coming attractions as well as exciting material for Palladium Fantasy, Heroes Unlimited and Rifts.

• A giant, 40 page advevture for the Palladium Fantasy Role-Playing Game, 2nd Ed., plus Hook, Line & Sinker adventures.
• Heroes Unlimited Motherframe: A powerful type of psionic augmentation and the agents who use it.
• P.P.E. Channeling for all Palladium game settings.
• Rifts: Strange and unusual familiars found on Rifts Earth.
• Rifts: The form and function of Techno-Wizardry.
• Rifts: Hammer of the Forge (fiction) - cliffhanger ending.
• News, what's coming from Palladium, and more.
• 96 pages of fun!

72492.name: Shatterhand
72492.description:
"Shatterhand is a side-scrolling action game for the Nintendo Entertainment System developed by Natsume and published by Jaleco in North America and Europe in 1991. It is an English localization of the Japanese Family Computer game Super Rescue Solbrain​, which was based on the tokusatsu series of the same title; although the license was removed from the NES version, resulting in a change to the game's graphics and plot."

Source: Wikipedia, "Shatterhand," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

72493.name: Dance Dance Revolution 2nd ReMIX
72493.description:
User summary:

The second Dance Dance Revolution release for the Playstation; a rhythm dancing game where the player must with his/her feet press the buttons on a special mat controller, according to the music's rhythm.

It was titled "ReMIX" and not "Mix", as you could change the disc to the Append Discs to get other songs.

72494.name: Super Dodge Ball
72494.description:
"Super Dodge Ball, released in Japan as Nekketsu Kōkō Dodgeball Bu (熱血高校ドッジボール部 Nekketsu Kōkō Dojjibōru Bu, "Nekketsu High School Dodgeball Club") is a dodgeball-based sports game released for the arcades and the Nintendo Entertainment System developed by Technos. Originally released in Japan as part of the Kunio-kun series, it was re-released for the Wii's Virtual Console in North America on September 22, 2008 at a cost of 500 Wii Points.

"

Source: Wikipedia, "Super_Dodge_Ball," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

72495.name: Mercenary Force
72495.description:
[User Summary]

In this little-known overhead shooter the player selects and then controls four characters based on tropes from Japanese historical fiction and cinema, arranging them strategically in real-time as waves of enemies attack.

72496.name: Reconstruction
72496.description:
Publisher blurb:

It is 1867. The American Civil War is over and the South is in ashes. Newly freed slaves mingle with former owners. Carpetbaggers and scallywags look for quick profits. Corruption is the coin of the realm, and the desperate, despicable and insane all look for an angle.

Written by our friend Tom Gurganus, this playset takes place in the still-smoldering ruins of southern Virginia.

72497.name: The Rifter (Issue 0 - May 2008)
rpgissuearticle: From the Keyboard of Matthew Daye
A Megaverse of Skills at your Fingertips
There’s Gold in them thar Hills!
72497.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Rifter® #Zero was created, in part, to help us celebrate The Rifters 10 Year Anniversary. It was never printed as a book, and was only be available as an electronic file download, making it the first Palladium downloadable product.

It has been compiled and put together by long-time Palladium fan, Matthew Daye and is pretty darn good. All contributors are Palladium fans looking to share their ideas with others.

Highlights for The Rifter® #0 Include:

A Megaverse® of Skills - a giant skill list compiled by Michael G. Totton, Jr.; all settings.
Known Worlds by Linwood Foster; for The Three Galaxies™.
Spells of the Arch Mage, a big and juicy hunk of magic source material, by Matthew Daye; for Rifts® and other Palladium settings.
Santa Claus by Josh Hilden, fun and funny; for Rifts®.
Weapons & Bio-Enhancements, by Chris Kluge; for Splicers®.
Seven Years on Cerebus for Splicers, Culture and Tradition, plus Ludicrous Magic rounds out the special edition.

72499.name: Tokimeki Memorial 3 – At That Place We Promised
72499.description:
User summary:

The third installment in Konami's famous series of dating simulation games. Tokimeki Memorial 3 retains the same game system as in the previous games, adding the aspect of choosing what to wear for the dates.

The player simulates 3 years of high school, and may each week choose what to concentrate on: Studies of various kinds, socializing, exercising, polishing his face, etc. Depending on what the player chooses, different stats will rise and sink, and depending on these stats, random "encounter" events with girls will occur. The player can then phone the girls he's encountered and invite them to dates, on which he might or might not impress the girl. The goal is to have one of the girls confess her love as the three high school years are at an end. However, Tokimemo 3 did not have the kind of intern parody humour as the first game did.

Tokimeki Memorial 3 featured full 3D cel-shaded graphics, and an improved system from Tokimeki Memorial 2, allowing the in-game characters to actually say the player's name.

72500.name: Final Fantasy Adventure
72500.description:
"Final Fantasy Adventure, known in Europe as Mystic Quest and originally released in Japan as Seiken Densetsu: Final Fantasy Gaiden, is a Final Fantasy spinoff and the first game in the Mana series. Released in 1991 on the original Game Boy, its gameplay is roughly similar to that of the original The Legend of Zelda game, but with the addition of role-playing statistical elements.

The story follows the hero and the young heroine as they attempt to thwart the Dark Lord of Glaive (Shadow Knight in the Japanese version) and his sorcerer assistant Julius from destroying the Tree of Mana and dooming their world. The game was met with generally positive reviews, noting its strong story but faulting its shaky dialogue, possibly due to the English translation."

Source: Wikipedia, "Final_Fantasy_Adventure," available under the CC-BY-SA License.
